name: Akira Yoshino
summary: Akira Yoshino is a Japanese chemist who shared the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing the first commercially viable lithium-ion battery. Working at Asahi Kasei Corporation, he used Goodenough's lithium cobalt oxide cathode with a carbon anode, creating a lightweight rechargeable battery that revolutionized portable electronics.
timeline: First commercial lithium-ion battery by Sony

name: Rachael Carson
summary: Already covered - see Rachel Carson. Duplicate check.

name: Stanley Whittingham
summary: Stanley Whittingham is a British-American chemist who shared the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his foundational work on lithium-ion batteries. At Exxon in the 1970s, he demonstrated that lithium ions could be stored in layered materials (titanium disulfide), creating the first rechargeable lithium battery concept that others later improved.

name: Barry Marshall
summary: Barry Marshall is an Australian physician who shared the 2005 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering that Helicobacter pylori bacteria cause peptic ulcers. When the medical establishment rejected his claims, he drank a H. pylori culture to prove it caused gastritis, then cured himself with antibiotics. This discovery revolutionized ulcer treatment.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University of Western Australia
Discovered H. pylori with Robin Warren
Drank H. pylori culture, developed gastritis
Published findings on bacterial cause of ulcers
Triple therapy became standard ulcer treatment
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Robin Warren
summary: Robin Warren is an Australian pathologist who shared the 2005 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for co-discovering that Helicobacter pylori causes gastritis and peptic ulcers. He first observed the spiral bacteria in stomach biopsies in 1979 and collaborated with Barry Marshall to prove they caused disease, overturning decades of medical dogma.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University of Adelaide
First observed H. pylori in gastric biopsies
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Harald zur Hausen
summary: Harald zur Hausen is a German virologist who won the 2008 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering that human papillomavirus (HPV) causes cervical cancer. His research in the 1980s identified HPV types 16 and 18 as the primary culprits, leading to the development of HPV vaccines that prevent cervical cancer.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University of Düsseldorf
Isolated HPV-16 from cervical cancer tissue
HPV vaccine developed based on his work
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Francoise Barre-Sinoussi
summary: Françoise Barré-Sinoussi is a French virologist who shared the 2008 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for co-discovering HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. In 1983 at the Pasteur Institute, she isolated the virus from a patient's lymph node, enabling the development of diagnostic tests and antiretroviral treatments that have saved millions of lives.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Paris
HIV blood test developed from her discovery
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Luc Montagnier
summary: Luc Montagnier was a French virologist who shared the 2008 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for co-discovering HIV. His laboratory at the Pasteur Institute identified the lymphadenopathy-associated virus (LAV) in 1983, later confirmed as the causative agent of AIDS. In later years, his controversial views on homeopathy and vaccines drew criticism.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Paris
Became head of Viral Oncology Unit at Institut Pasteur
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Youyou Tu
summary: Already covered - see Tu Youyou. Duplicate.

name: Kary Mullis
summary: Kary Mullis was an American biochemist who invented the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), one of the most important tools in molecular biology. PCR enables scientists to make millions of copies of a specific DNA sequence, revolutionizing genetics, forensics, diagnostics, and research. He won the 1993 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for this invention.

name: Frederick Sanger
summary: Frederick Sanger was a British biochemist who is one of only four people to win two Nobel Prizes. He won in 1958 for determining the amino acid sequence of insulin and in 1980 for inventing the Sanger method of DNA sequencing. His DNA sequencing technique made the Human Genome Project possible and remains one of the most important methods in biology.
timeline: Determined complete amino acid sequence of insulin
Awarded first Nobel Prize in Chemistry
Awarded second Nobel Prize in Chemistry

name: Francois Jacob
summary: François Jacob was a French biologist who shared the 1965 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering the genetic regulation of enzyme and virus synthesis (the operon model). With Jacques Monod, he showed how genes can be switched on and off, establishing the field of gene regulation. He also proposed the concept of messenger RNA.
timeline: Joined Free French Forces, severely wounded
Earned doctorate from University of Paris
Proposed operon model with Jacques Monod
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Jacques Monod
summary: Jacques Monod was a French biochemist who shared the 1965 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering the mechanism of gene regulation. With François Jacob, he developed the operon model showing how genes are turned on and off in response to environmental signals. His book 'Chance and Necessity' was an influential philosophical work on biology.
timeline: Published operon model with François Jacob
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: James Watson
summary: James Watson is an American molecular biologist who co-discovered the double helix structure of DNA with Francis Crick in 1953, using X-ray data from Rosalind Franklin. He shared the 1962 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. He led the Human Genome Project from 1990-1992. His later controversial comments on race led to widespread criticism.
timeline: Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Francis Crick
summary: Francis Crick was a British molecular biologist and physicist who co-discovered the double helix structure of DNA in 1953. He shared the 1962 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with James Watson and Maurice Wilkins. He also proposed the Central Dogma of molecular biology (DNA → RNA → Protein) and co-discovered the triplet genetic code.
timeline: Co-discovered DNA double helix with Watson
Proposed Central Dogma of molecular biology
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Oswald Avery
summary: Oswald Avery was a Canadian-American physician and molecular biologist who demonstrated in 1944 that DNA is the substance that carries genetic information, not protein as previously believed. His Avery-MacLeod-McCarty experiment was one of the most important discoveries in biology, establishing DNA as the molecule of heredity, though he was never awarded a Nobel Prize.
timeline: Born in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada
Published proof that DNA is the genetic material

name: Jonas Salk
summary: Jonas Salk was an American virologist who developed the first successful polio vaccine in 1955. His inactivated poliovirus vaccine was safe and effective, preventing a disease that had paralyzed thousands annually. He famously refused to patent the vaccine, saying 'Could you patent the sun?' His vaccine was one of the greatest public health achievements of the 20th century.
timeline: Earned MD from New York University
Began polio vaccine research at University of Pittsburgh
Polio vaccine approved for public use
Founded Salk Institute for Biological Studies

name: Albert Sabin
summary: Albert Sabin was a Polish-American virologist who developed the oral polio vaccine (OPV), using a weakened live virus. His oral vaccine was cheaper, easier to administer than Salk's injected vaccine, and provided longer-lasting immunity. It became the dominant polio vaccine worldwide and was crucial for the near-eradication of polio globally.
timeline: Born in Białystok, Russian Empire (now Poland)
Earned MD from New York University
OPV approved in the United States

name: Alexander Fleming
summary: Alexander Fleming was a Scottish bacteriologist who discovered penicillin in 1928 when he noticed that a mold (Penicillium notatum) had killed bacteria on a culture plate. This accidental discovery led to the development of antibiotics, which have saved an estimated 200 million lives. He shared the 1945 Nobel Prize with Howard Florey and Ernst Chain.
timeline: Graduated from St Mary's Hospital Medical School
Florey and Chain developed penicillin for clinical use
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Selman Abraham Waksman
summary: Already covered - see Selman Waksman. Duplicate check.

name: Werner Heisenberg
summary: Werner Heisenberg was a German physicist who created quantum mechanics and formulated the uncertainty principle. His matrix mechanics (1925) was the first complete mathematical framework for quantum theory. The Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that certain pairs of physical properties cannot be simultaneously known with arbitrary precision.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Munich

name: Erwin Schrodinger
summary: Erwin Schrödinger was an Austrian physicist who developed wave mechanics and the Schrödinger equation, which describes how quantum states evolve over time. He shared the 1933 Nobel Prize in Physics. His famous Schrödinger's cat thought experiment illustrated the paradoxes of quantum superposition. He also wrote 'What is Life?' which influenced molecular biology.

name: Niels Bohr
summary: Niels Bohr was a Danish physicist who made foundational contributions to understanding atomic structure and quantum theory. His Bohr model of the atom (1913) introduced quantum energy levels and explained hydrogen's emission spectrum. He won the 1922 Nobel Prize in Physics and was instrumental in developing the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Copenhagen
Proposed Bohr model of the atom

name: Enrico Fermi
summary: Enrico Fermi was an Italian-American physicist who created the first controlled nuclear chain reaction in 1942 and made major contributions to nuclear physics, quantum theory, and particle physics. He won the 1938 Nobel Prize for demonstrating the existence of new radioactive elements through neutron irradiation. He was one of the most versatile physicists of the 20th century.
timeline: Fled Italy to the United States
Created first nuclear chain reaction (Chicago Pile-1)

name: Robert Oppenheimer
summary: J. Robert Oppenheimer was an American theoretical physicist who led the Manhattan Project that developed the first nuclear weapons during WWII. Known as the 'father of the atomic bomb,' he later opposed the hydrogen bomb and was controversially stripped of his security clearance during the McCarthy era. He made contributions to quantum mechanics and astrophysics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Göttingen
Appointed scientific director of Manhattan Project
Became director of Institute for Advanced Study

name: Marie Curie
summary: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist and chemist who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, the first person to win two Nobel Prizes, and remains the only person to win Nobel Prizes in two different sciences (Physics 1903, Chemistry 1911). She discovered radium and polonium, pioneered radioactivity research, and developed mobile X-ray units for WWI.
timeline: Moved to Paris to study at Sorbonne
Became first female professor at Sorbonne
Developed mobile X-ray units for WWI
Died of aplastic anemia from radiation exposure

name: Dmitri Mendeleev
summary: Dmitri Mendeleev was a Russian chemist who created the periodic table of elements in 1869, arranging elements by atomic weight and predicting the properties of elements not yet discovered. His predictions of gallium, scandium, and germanium were later confirmed with remarkable accuracy. The periodic table remains the most important organizing principle in chemistry.
timeline: Published first periodic table of elements

name: Antoine Lavoisier
summary: Antoine Lavoisier was a French chemist known as the 'Father of Modern Chemistry.' He named oxygen and hydrogen, disproved phlogiston theory, established the law of conservation of mass, and wrote the first modern chemistry textbook. He also helped develop the metric system. He was guillotined during the French Revolution despite his scientific contributions.
timeline: Elected to French Academy of Sciences
Stated law of conservation of mass

name: Louis Pasteur
summary: Louis Pasteur was a French chemist and microbiologist who proved germ theory, developed pasteurization, and created vaccines for anthrax and rabies. His work saved millions of lives by establishing that microorganisms cause disease and food spoilage. He disproved spontaneous generation and founded the Pasteur Institute, one of the world's premier research centers.

name: Robert Koch
summary: Robert Koch was a German physician who identified the bacteria causing tuberculosis, cholera, and anthrax. He developed Koch's postulates, the criteria for establishing a causal link between a microbe and a disease. He won the 1905 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. His methods for isolating bacteria revolutionized medical microbiology.
timeline: Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Ivan Pavlov
summary: Ivan Pavlov was a Russian physiologist who won the 1904 Nobel Prize for his work on the physiology of digestion. He is best known for his discovery of classical conditioning (Pavlov's dogs), demonstrating that reflexive responses can be triggered by associated stimuli. His conditioned reflex research became foundational to behavioral psychology and neuroscience.
timeline: Earned medical degree from Imperial Medical Academy
Became professor at Imperial Medical Academy
Published 'Lectures on the Work of the Digestive Glands'
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Santiago Ramon y Cajal
summary: Already covered. Duplicate check.

name: Wilhelm Rontgen
summary: Wilhelm Röntgen was a German physicist who discovered X-rays in 1895, for which he received the first Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901. His discovery revolutionized medicine by enabling doctors to see inside the human body without surgery. He refused to patent his discovery, believing it should benefit all humanity.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Zurich
Became professor at University of Würzburg
Took first medical X-ray (his wife's hand)
Received first Nobel Prize in Physics

name: Henri Becquerel
summary: Henri Becquerel was a French physicist who discovered radioactivity in 1896 while studying phosphorescent materials. He noticed that uranium salts emitted radiation that could fog photographic plates without exposure to sunlight. He shared the 1903 Nobel Prize in Physics with Pierre and Marie Curie for this discovery that opened the atomic age.
timeline: Became professor at Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle

name: Ernest Rutherford
summary: Ernest Rutherford was a New Zealand-born British physicist known as the 'Father of Nuclear Physics.' He discovered the concept of radioactive half-life, proved that alpha rays are helium nuclei, and in 1911 his gold foil experiment revealed the atomic nucleus. He won the 1908 Nobel Prize in Chemistry and was the first to split the atom (1917).
timeline: Moved to Cambridge to study under J.J. Thomson
First to split the atom (nitrogen disintegration)

name: J.J. Thomson
summary: J.J. Thomson was a British physicist who discovered the electron in 1897 through his cathode ray experiments, proving that atoms are not indivisible. He proposed the 'plum pudding' model of the atom and won the 1906 Nobel Prize in Physics. Seven of his research students also won Nobel Prizes, including his son George Paget Thomson.

name: Michael Faraday
summary: Michael Faraday was a British physicist and chemist who made foundational discoveries in electromagnetism and electrochemistry. He discovered electromagnetic induction, the principle behind electric generators and transformers. He also discovered benzene, developed the laws of electrolysis, and invented the Faraday cage. Despite no formal education, he became one of the greatest scientists ever.
timeline: Born in Newington Butts, Surrey, England
Became assistant to Humphry Davy at Royal Institution

name: Hans Christian Orsted
summary: Hans Christian Ørsted was a Danish physicist and chemist who discovered electromagnetism in 1820 when he observed that an electric current deflected a compass needle. This discovery of the relationship between electricity and magnetism was one of the most important in physics, leading to the development of electric motors, generators, and telecommunications.
timeline: Became professor at University of Copenhagen

name: Andre-Marie Ampere
summary: André-Marie Ampère was a French physicist and mathematician who founded the science of electrodynamics (now called electromagnetism). He formulated Ampère's law relating electric current to magnetic fields and demonstrated that parallel wires carrying current exert forces on each other. The SI unit of electric current (ampere) is named after him.
timeline: Formulated Ampère's law following Ørsted's discovery

name: Georg Ohm
summary: Georg Ohm was a German physicist who discovered Ohm's law (1827), the fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in electrical circuits. His law states that current is proportional to voltage and inversely proportional to resistance. Initially rejected, his work was eventually recognized as foundational to electrical engineering.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Erlangen
Became professor at Jesuit Gymnasium, Cologne
Became professor at University of Munich

name: Alessandro Volta
summary: Alessandro Volta was an Italian physicist who invented the voltaic pile in 1800, the first true electric battery. His invention provided the first reliable source of continuous electric current, enabling all subsequent electrical experimentation. The volt, the SI unit of electric potential, is named in his honor. He also discovered methane gas.
timeline: Born in Como, Duchy of Milan
Became physics professor at Royal School of Como
Became professor at University of Pavia

name: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb
summary: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb was a French physicist who formulated Coulomb's law (1785), describing the electrostatic force between charged particles. He developed the torsion balance to precisely measure these forces. His law is fundamental to electrostatics and is one of the basic equations of electromagnetism. The coulomb unit of electric charge bears his name.
timeline: Won Academy prize for magnetic compass research

name: Heinrich Hertz
summary: Heinrich Hertz was a German physicist who was the first to prove the existence of electromagnetic waves predicted by Maxwell's theory. In 1887, he generated and detected radio waves using a spark gap transmitter. His experiments confirmed Maxwell's equations and laid the foundation for radio, television, and wireless communications. The hertz unit is named after him.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Berlin
Published proof of Maxwell's electromagnetic theory
Died of Wegener's granulomatosis in Bonn at age 36

name: Maxwell's demon
summary: Already covered - see James Clerk Maxwell. Duplicate check.

name: Guglielmo Marconi
summary: Guglielmo Marconi was an Italian inventor and electrical engineer who pioneered long-distance radio transmission. He sent the first wireless telegraph signal across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901 and shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in Physics. His work launched the wireless communication revolution that led to radio broadcasting, television, and modern telecommunications.
timeline: Sent first wireless signal across English Channel

name: Nils Gustaf Dalen
summary: Nils Gustaf Dalén was a Swedish physicist and inventor who won the 1912 Nobel Prize in Physics for his invention of automatic regulators for gas-powered lighthouse beacons. His AGA lighthouse technology saved lives at sea and reduced operating costs. He lost his eyesight in an explosion during experiments but continued his inventive career despite blindness.
timeline: Invented sun valve for automatic lighthouses

name: Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff
summary: Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff was a Dutch chemist who won the first Nobel Prize in Chemistry (1901) for discovering the laws of chemical dynamics and osmotic pressure. He also proposed the tetrahedral arrangement of carbon bonds, founding stereochemistry. His work in physical chemistry laid foundations for understanding reaction rates and solution behavior.
timeline: Awarded first Nobel Prize in Chemistry

name: Svante Arrhenius
summary: Already covered. Duplicate check.

name: Fritz Haber
summary: Fritz Haber was a German chemist who invented the Haber-Bosch process for synthesizing ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen, enabling the mass production of fertilizers. This invention is estimated to have enabled food production for nearly half the world's current population. He won the 1918 Nobel Prize but remains controversial for developing chemical weapons in WWI.
timeline: Born in Breslau, Prussia (now Wrocław, Poland)
Earned PhD from Technical University of Berlin
Demonstrated ammonia synthesis from nitrogen and hydrogen
Directed first chlorine gas attack in WWI

name: Alfred Nobel
summary: Alfred Nobel was a Swedish chemist and inventor who invented dynamite, ballistite, and gelignite, holding 355 patents. He amassed a fortune from explosives manufacturing. In his will, he established the Nobel Prizes, funding the world's most prestigious awards in physics, chemistry, medicine, literature, and peace. The Nobel Prizes have been awarded since 1901.
timeline: Read his own premature obituary calling him 'merchant of death'

name: Carl Linnaeus
summary: Carl Linnaeus was a Swedish botanist and zoologist who created the binomial nomenclature system for naming species (Genus species) that is still used today. His Systema Naturae organized all known living organisms into a hierarchical classification. Known as the 'Father of Modern Taxonomy,' he formalized the system that enables scientists worldwide to communicate about species.
timeline: Published first edition of Systema Naturae
Published 10th edition of Systema Naturae (zoological nomenclature)

name: Gregor Mendel
summary: Gregor Mendel was an Augustinian friar and scientist who discovered the fundamental laws of inheritance through his experiments with pea plants. His work, published in 1866, established the concepts of dominant and recessive traits and the laws of segregation and independent assortment. Ignored during his lifetime, his work was rediscovered in 1900 and became the foundation of genetics.
timeline: Born in Hynčice, Austrian Empire (now Czech Republic)
Work rediscovered by de Vries, Correns, and Tschermak

name: Charles Darwin
summary: Charles Darwin was a British naturalist who developed the theory of evolution by natural selection, one of the most important scientific ideas in history. His observations during the voyage of the Beagle and years of careful research led to On the Origin of Species (1859). His theory explained how species change over time through differential survival and reproduction.
timeline: Began five-year voyage on HMS Beagle
Returned to England with specimens and observations
Presented theory jointly with Alfred Russel Wallace
